I've had these sorts of mood swings in the past, around the same time that I started to feel ovulation pain, when I was 14 years old. But now, several years later, it's rare for me to get mood swings related to my cycle. However, I still get 1 PMS symptom every single month, even when I don't have ovulation pain, chest pain. My chest hurts about a week before my period. I also tend to ovulate late, as my ovulation pain, when I do have it doesn't hit around day 14, but around day 20. So I'm a third week ovulator I guess you could say. And I do have ovarian cysts, but I can definitely tell ovulation apart from ruptured ovarian cyst. My ovulation pain used to come with nausea that was only relieved by ginger tea, but that's not the case anymore, I don't get ovulation-induced nausea anymore.

ASAPScience, I expected better from you:
3:05 "one woman's PMS is not like the others', which is why health professionals have a tough time finding a clear understanding of how it all works"

So, to start, the notion that menstrual biology is uniquely complicated needs to be thrown out. Many aspects of medicine vary from person to person, from pain management (a famous one) to mental health. Second, menstrual health and PMS is understudied compared to other conditions. Women themselves are understudied - 80% of pain studies are conducted on male men or male mice, leading to poorer pain management in non-men. Third, there is some well-documented bias in the clinic - including menstrual issues and women's pain care. We are not far beyond the days of treating PMS as "hysteria." Honestly, the notion that womens biology is inherently more nebulous and mysterious is such a lazy viewpoint, and its "lost cause" implication perpetuates the same sexist attitudes that lead to these issues continuing to be understudied. That part of the video could have been a lot better on a science channel.

So, I guess you could say that bad science makes women moody.

Sincerely, a tired health research professional.

Edit

I’m a man, just curious about this.

My parents were pretty liberal and open but I had almost no idea what was going on with my period. There was a huge media sensation because a woman wrote an older kids novel in which a young woman gets her period at some point in the story. It was shocking and controversial and very progressive.( Are you there God ? Its me Margaret.) I guess my parents thought it taught me everything I needed to know and they were off the hook. It didn't though.   I woke up in sixth grade and I had bled and I thought, " Well that's over". I was too embarrassed to say  anything so  I put a few washcloths in my pants just in case some left over blood came out and went to school. At noon I went home for lunch because I was starting to feel awful and no one was home. My abdomen started hurting like crazy and not only wasn't the bleeding over it was getting much worse. I was convinced something had gone terribly wrong like something had ruptured and I was dying. I laid on my bed convinced I would probably be dead by the time anyone came home and didn't go back to school but curled up to await death. There was no 911 and I didn't know the number for help and I preferred death by hemorrhage to death by embarrassment.  My mom came home and my fear of death overcame my embarrassment and I confessed the tragic news. My mom hooked me up and explained it all and gave me a hot water bottle and aspirin. In 1974 there was  no Tylenol or ibuprofen the miracle drug so it didn't help much. Have you guys heard about PMDD ?
It's called pre menstrual dysphoric disorder. It's basically PMSx1000. It causes fatigue, insomnia, lethargy, depression, anger, strong anxiety etc. and in 15% of cases, it can lead to suicide. The symptoms usually start a week before your period but they also can start right after ovulation. They usually stop on the first day or a few days in your period. It is often misdiagnosed as rapid cycling bipolar 2 disorder but many women. If you feel like you suffer from pmdd or if you think someone you know suffers from it, check the gia allemand website and/or ask around in the different pmdd support group on Facebook, we'll be happy to help you understand what's going on.
Also, symptom diary is always the key :)

Wrong. The sperm fertilizes in the fallopian tube, which is the wide opening next to the ovary, in 1 day after it was released.8 It dies after 1 day, and takes about 4 days to move to the uterus. Thus, sperm cannot fertilize an egg in the uterus, only in the fallopian tube. So if there's a baby, it will have reached a further stage of cell spliting, so that it's good to dig itself in the uterine lining that's been building up for those 4 days mentioned earlier. If that happends, hormones are sent to the body so that the lining doesn't break off. That's pregnancy. If not, the yellow body thats the bag the ripe egg was in in the ovary, will die and the hormones will not be sent to the body, thus brealing off the uterine lining, causing a period. Can you all study some psychology and realize that increased hormones in the brain do not necessarily corroloate with more intense moods. Studies that used men as a controll group kept track of woman's emotions and saw no significant corrolation between PMS and worse moods. The world believing this makes it a self fulfilling prophecy where women believe they're more irratable during PMS. Want proof. Ask a woman who thinks PMS happens during her period if she is emotional during the time and she will probably say yes. Women who know PMS happens before their period will report worse moods prior to their period. Their significant others will probably also agree with them. Cultures who are not told about angry moods during PMS do not report them.........

Ive had all the symtoms. The first decade pretty much I would get the physical symtoms really bad(like life halting bad) and barely any of the emotional and psychological ones except depression. Now the physical ones are less, I get sore boobies a week prior to bleeding and I get some joint and back pain and the bad cramps only last for 2 hrs instead of like 12 and then only very light cramps the rest of the day, some cold sweats. BUT I get this one day of full on crankiness and irritability about 3 to 5 days before period, a lot of strong food cravings, weepy for at least 3 days crying if something is either happy or sad, I get really hyper like 4-5 days before(like right before the angry part) and get a lot of stuff done and then I feel sad, very fatigued and tired till day two of my period when i get another boost of energy. Im hoping after this second decade I can be rid of all the symtoms so I can really enjoy my life before I get menopause. That's a whole other ordeal. I know women who had such a bad reaction to menopause that they would blank out in rage and even forget who their family members were. And it wasn't dementia because they went back to normal when their hormones leveled out or when they got hormonal treatment.

What you are saying is not 100% true. I took sexology classes and they  explained it really clearly. So first of all period is actually when the inside layer of the uterus falls so a new one can be created so the egg will be able to stay in the uterus once fertilized. Then  a few days after period (like around 2 weeks) an ovule is liberated from the ovaries but it only goes in the fallopian tube. It doesn’t go to the uterus before it is fertilized by the spermatozoid. So when spermatozoid come inside of the woman they have to go all the way from the vagina to the fallopian tube and a lot of things are in their way to make it harder. By the way i also wanted to mention not every woman menstrual cycle is 28 days actually it can vary from 25 i think to 31 and actually studies have shown woman who have a cycle around 30 are much more likely to have childs easily

Shit like this video is why people think women cannot be leaders or in charge of anything serious, which is an absurd notion considering what testosterone does to men.  Cramps are primarily caused by our shitty modern diets, low in magnesium and potassium.  That's literally all you need to do for that part.  Estrogen and serotonin, that's a little different but there are various regional plants (every region has at least a few that were regularly consumed by humans) that actually contain compounds that modulate hormones and neurotransmitters (for both sexes).  But we don't really eat those very much anymore, unless you're a hippie (I guess lol, or someone who buys extracts from health nut stores like me), or living in a third world country where food sources have less variety.   Telling everyone it's okay for a woman to act like a B, or to actually celebrate such behavior, actually makes her likelier to be that way and be less capable or willing of self-monitoring (same as telling girls they are bad at math, or telling boys they are good at math, same as telling boys it's alright for them to show aggression).  PMS is not entirely natural, this is why every woman has wildly different so-called PMS symptoms, and why some have none at all and have no idea a period is coming other than the date on the calendar (which is the way it should be).  It's a huge evolutionary disadvantage for a female of any species to be regularly crippled enough that their ability to hunt or flee predators in compromised (because they're in pain or feel sick/tired) or problem-solve or appropriately respond to environmental stimuli in her usual rational manner (which would be a threat not only to the female directly, but any offspring she might have at the time).  Other than that I enjoy your videos, thanks for making them.

I believe society needs to realize that pain does not excuse bad behavior. I've had 12 concussions over the course of 5 years from MMA and have just gotten over Second Impact Syndrome and with a few outstanding moments aside, did not complain nearly as much as the people in this comments section about their period. And I'm not alone, there are plenty of people going through similar or worse pain than I did, and still get less easily irritated than some(not all) women do on their period(mainly referring to those in the comments section complaining about how bad it is and how "we'll never know what it feels like"). Also as a side note, both my friend and I had noticed that our endurance with regards to pain increased exponentially the more often it happened, so although I can't state unanimously that this is the case for periods, one would think that eventually you'd become less prone to it, especially if it is as bad as they say. We're comparing how a broken arm feels now, vs how it did 10 years ago or so. It's very easy to cope now.

Again, just trying to bring in an opposition to those who think of their period as an excuse to be "moody". Feel bad if you must, but don't make other people feel your wrath just because you can't deal with it for a week.

When an ovum is released and travels through the Fallopian tube, it has a small yellow swelling on it,, known as the corpus luteum, or yellow body. While the egg is there, the corpus luteum secretes progesterone, which helps build up and maintain the womb lining while the egg is there. In the event of fertilisation, a placenta eventually forms which takes over the job of producing progesterone. But if not, then the egg is flushed out along with the corpus luteum, so there is nothing there to maintain the womb lining, which is why it breaks down. The question is, why can we not just secrete progestrone all the time?

1. Drink lots and lots of pure water-every chemical reaction in the human body needs water


2. Exercise consistently and frequently-a blend of aerobic exercise and weightlifting


3. Eat lots of vegetables-raw is best 


4. Sleep 7-8 hours of every 24 in near total darkness


5. Avoid sugar, even fruit, during your period


6. Don't drink or eat cold things during your period


7. Exercise your lower abdomen-targeted ab workouts, belly dance

I didn't really understand the video. 

Are they saying that all women have PMS? I had heard before that only some women experience that particular issue.

Also, it seems a bit counter-intuitive to suggest that women wouldn't get upset or feel irritable during the period itself because of the pain. Aren't people generally pretty cranky when they're in pain? "Moody" is a vague term, so explaining that PMS happens separately from the period doesn't really tell us anything about whether a woman's mood could be impacted by the physical experience of the period itself.

I didn't really like the implication that women are totally at the mercy of their biology and need understanding because they are almost certainly going to behave in an erratic, emotional manner during that time of month. Some parts of the video struck me as mild insults veiled in the form of sympathy and logic. I know far too many women who manage to perform consistently despite hormonal fluctuations, and who do not simply lose control every month.

In any case, I don't think people should tolerate bad behavior or unreasonable demands from women based on this, and certainly not physical violence. To me, women deserve no less than to be treated as rational agents who are in control of their actions, and I can't really see treating them as if they are "compromised" on a monthly basis as a positive thing for the women's rights movement.

Like the video said, its science. Hormonal changes are natural in females and thus changes in mood is natural. One can be aware of such changes and find ways to cope with it which is something fairly common that we go through as a species living in today's world. Its not like we can go around yelling at our colleagues and bosses in the workplace without facing consequences for it. So while some people could use it as an excuse we cannot deny that these natural mood changes are genuinely something that women go through every month.

Those women who are man-haters and want female world domination are not feminists. Feminism is an act that benefits both men and women. Have we achieved this ideal world? Just keep in mind that, like the video said, everyone has a different experience! Some people experience mild symptoms while others are severe. Genetics can play a great part in this. All of the women in my family never found relief of symptoms with age like some women experience, and I naturally pulled the same cards.

In addition, other conditions and factors can irritate or worsen the symptoms. Due to neurocardiogenic syncope, I find it very difficult to walk without severe pain and muscle fatigue in my legs during my cycle (among many other nasty symptoms). This problem seems to be getting worse as I grow older, and that is just as common as the opposite from what I can gather. Coupled with the fact that everyone experiences and rates pain differently, it's nigh impossible to come up with comparisons for those who have never experienced a cycle for themselves.

Moral of the story: respect other people's pain! This can gauge whether or not that person can function normally at any specific time. And heating pads go a long way!

For the guys who have no idea what a period feels like...if you've ever been kicked in the nuts and felt that pain that completely fills your pelvis and shoots up into your stomach, actually you kind of do. Really, it's the same set of nerves being stimulated. Except for guys getting kicked in the nuts, it's a 1-shot stimulus. For girls that pain comes in increasingly painful waves that can take hours to peak and a day or more to resolve. So I guess you'd have a fairly accurate impression of the pain if you put your nuts in a vice grip, crank up the pressure over the course of 2-3 hours until your nuts are on the verge of bursting and leave it like that for another 6 to 24 hours...and took cheap laxatives right around the time of onset so they'd go to work right about the time the pain is at its worst.

3. It hurts. The pain varies from person to person, from mild pain to something that feels like stabbing. I had the stabbing feeling once before and I had to go to the nurses office to get a hotpad. I cried for a few minutes because it really hurts to the point of immobilization. Sometimes, it's not even just cramps. Sometimes, it's something weird, like back pain or soreness. 
4. The hormones just spike up everywhere. Guys have hormones too, but I'm not sure if their levels spike up to the same degree that girls do during their periods. My friend has is pretty bad where the spike in hormones causes her to break out in pimples. FYI, no it's not puberty. She's an adult now and still has to deal with acne when she's on her period.
5. You think it's over, but it's not. When I first got it, I was relieved to see a clean pad and took it off, only to have it flow again within the next few hours. 
6. Stomach problems. Sometimes, I get bloated. Other times, I get the runs. Let me tell you, getting diarrhea while you're at school is one of the most embarassing things ever.

I'm sure there's more, but these are things I've experience. It may differ from woman-to-woman, but the fact remains that having periods aren't fun. It doesn't excuse a woman from being a HUGE BITCH, but at least try to understand why they're acting like that.

Guys guys guys. All the comments about how it "shouldn't be that hard" or "you should be able to control it" or even "PMS doesn't give a girl the right to bitch".

Okay. I will concede that PMS does NOT give us a right to bitch. That much is true. However, the fact of the matter is that PMS changes around the chemicals in our brains. Now, these chemicals and the way they change vary from person to person, but they DO change. Another fact: some women have more self-control than others. That's just how it is.

So while PMS doesn't give us the right to bitch, it sure does change our moods.

tl;dr - PMS is an explanation, not an excuse. Also, PMS varies from woman to woman; no woman will experience PMS in the exact same way.

I'm also extremely aware of my emotional state and so have maybe slightly better control over it?

But your hormones are not "going crazy" during PMS - they're doing what they're supposed to do.  Maybe there's something wrong with our society that cannot accommodate PMS or has unrealistic expectation of women at this time.  Don't like to generalize but if we were socialized to expect and prep for PMS and were accommodated socially AND were taught to respect and honour this cycle we women might experience it differently.  In Anishinabe teachings the "moon time" is considered sacred.  It is honoured, respected and accommodated in many ways in the culture - although decolonizing one's mindset and practices is necessary in order to do that.

Good ole nature at its finest :) Now there is a lot more than what this video explains, as the menstrual cycle is extremely complicated (and immensely fascinating if you wish to learn about it) Like how sex can make periods less painful and shorter. Or how pain tends to go down with age. Or even why cramps even occur. But remember this: This is a natural occurrence, its out of our control, its different for everyone, and if you are insensitive watch your self. We don't have to cater to you ;D. Empathy and knowledge is the most helpful tool a guy can have during this time. Because if some lady is like me, gets full of pure rage instead of tears when I am in pain (think berserker status rage here.), try to understand what is causing it and why.

Communication is everything ;) Because how are we supposed to be equals if we don't understand and talk with each other.

I applaud you guys at AsapSCIENCE (and iiSuperwomanii) for making a great educational video on the basics of the menstrual cycle, however I wanted to point out that some research (like that of Dr. Gillian Einstein from the University of Toronto, Canada) suggests that the idea of PMS is more of a social construct than a consistently significant predictor of mood. That's not to say that it doesn't exist, but I find that the video put too much emphasis on the stereotypical experience of PMS (eg irritability, the need to cry, etc) and not enough on the fact that not everyone has these experiences. I only want to point this out because I find it pretty annoying when a woman may be acting a certain way, and she gets asked if it's PMS (which, in effect, kind of invalidates her feelings). Just my two cents!

So many comments that say "you don't have to act like a biotch just because of hormonal changes."
You're not understanding how it works. Women don't look at the calendar and say "hey, my hormones are out of whack. Men, hear me roar!"
It's involuntary. One day, we'll just suddenly feel really sad for no reason at all, or get super mad over dumb stuff that we normally wouldn't get angry at. It's NOT a conscious decision. It's our bodies creating the hormones and our brains interpreting them and all the physical chemistry that causes it, which is not exactly under our control. I swear, when these things happen, we're confused at why we feel the occasional urge to hulk smash things, or why we suddenly get all depressed. Once we realize that it's probably just PMS, then we'll try to get it under control, but like I said, it's not a conscious decision. You can't just turn off sadness or anger, just like you can't consciously stop your heart from beating.

On average, women have 34 nerve fibers per square centimeter of facial skin. Men average just 17. Translation = because there are more nerves to receive pain in women than men, if a woman and man are say slapped across the face using the exact same amount of force, the woman will feel it more intensely. Meaning there is no way to solve the scrotum-kicking-same-as-period-pain argument, because there is no way to make a woman feel the pain of being kicked in the scrotum in the same way as a man, and no way of making a man feel the same pain as a woman on her period in the same way as women do - because they would hurt differently on the other sex. Also I'm not saying the bit at the beginning to say that women have it harder or men have it harder. They both have it hard in different ways. Basically being human sucks, but so does being anything. Being human is also amazing though, because we are the apex predator. Why? Because we have adapted in ways that other species couldn't and fast too. A married couple went to the hospital together to have their baby delivered. Upon their arrival, the doctor said he had invented a new machine that would transfer a portion of the mother's labor pain to the father. He asked if they were willing to try it out. They were both very much in favor of it.

The doctor set the knob to 10 percent for starters, explaining that even 10 percent was probably more pain than the father had ever experienced before.

But as the labor progressed, the husband felt fine, so he asked the doctor to go ahead and bump it up a notch. The doctor then adjusted the machine to 20 percent pain transfer.

The husband was still feeling fine. The doctor checked the husband's blood pressure and pulse and was amazed at how well he was doing. At this, they decided to try for 50 percent. The husband continued to feel quite well.

Since it was obviously helping out his wife considerably, he encouraged the doctor to transfer ALL the pain to him. The wife delivered a healthy baby with virtually no pain. She and her husband were ecstatic.

When they got home, the mailman was dead on their porch

Atresia begins at birth and continues throughout the course of the woman's reproductive life. When a woman reaches puberty and starts to menstruate, only about 400,000 follicles remain. With each menstrual cycle, a thousand follicles are lost and only one lucky little follicle will actually mature into an ovum (egg), which is released into the fallopian tube, kicking off ovulation. You forgot some important points to mention.  First off, not only is PMS different in all women who have it, but not all women experience PMS symptoms at all.  In fact, true medical cases of PMS is rare.  However, all women do experience their period and the time leading up to it differently.

Secondly, PMS does not necessarily mean that women are inherently emotional or irrational.  Many women do face mood swings during this time, or other things that may cause us to act irrational, but usually if we are mad at you there is probably a reason.  Remember, most of us have been going through this cycle since middle school or high school.  WE know what our symptoms are and we know how to handle them.  Just because we disagree with you, or get made when you eat all of our favorite foods, does not mean we are "PMSing" or "crazy".

Lastly, there has been a common consensus in the medical community until just recently that most unexplainable symptoms in women are caused by PMS.  This includes depression, reactions to traumatic events such as abuse, and actual deadly problems involving our periods such as endometriosis.  Look, we know when something is wrong and when it's just PMS.  It's not a "female psychosis".  We are human just like you.  So please remember that when hear of our troubles.  It might surprise you how often the phrase "Oh, she's just PMSing." is completely off the mark.

1) women are necessary for the human race. And before we hear any one saying "we deserve something for dealing with women," or "men are just as important as women." There are other ways. To address the stuff that most of the guys have been saying here: I partially disagree with you all, and I partially agree.  As a teen girl you gets pretty bad mood swings during PMS, I can honestly say that it is so hard for me to control those emotions.  I cry over little things, I get nauseous and irritable.  In fact, I'll often catch myself saying things and a few seconds later be wondering how I could ever say something so harsh.  (For the record, I have female friends who have PMS just as bad while some don't suffer at all.)  But, yes, it is important not to let those emotions take over.  Girls shouldn't deny that you are feeling terrible, but they should also try to be as positive as possible, and not make others feel like crap too.  And MOST IMPORTANTLY, PMS should NOT be used as an excuse to act like a brat!  There are definitely times when girls are moody and snappy, but it's the chemicals in our brains - WE CAN'T HELP IT.  That's why I really dislike it when I see some girls (not all.  SOME.  NOT ALL) using that to their advantage and purposely being rude, then saying, "I'm on my period, GOSH."

The amygdala doesn't deal with emotions, it deals with empathy. Saying it deals with emotions and it increases in activity at the time implies that the only effect of PMS is that women become moody and irrational. The amygdala is incredibly critical in maintaining healthy interpersonal relationships for the average person, and it increasing in activity would actually be beneficial. It does also deal with snap judgments, but not in an emotional, irrational way, but as an efficient means of quickly gathering and interpreting information about people (which can unfortunately also lend itself to maintaining subconscious prejudice)

Great video and one that is much needed to help create better understanding of what causes PMS.  There could be a better distinction made in this video between estrogen and progesterone hormones, however.  During the first two weeks after menstruation begins progesterone drops and estrogen rises.  These are the "feel good" weeks of a woman's cycle.  Estrogen actually helps to promote the happy neurochemical's effects in our brains and is even good for our brain cells.  Midway through the cycle, right around when ovulation occurs, estrogen starts dropping and progesterone begins to rise and then meets estrogen halfway.  As estrogen drops and progesterone increases, the "happy times" start fading, and the icky feelings that occur during pms start to flutter in.  Then all sh*t hits the fan a few days before the actual period when both progesterone and estrogen drop completely and the brain has to deal with this lack of both hormones that have been around for a good 3 1/2 weeks.  It doesn't deal with this very well and this is what causes all the moodiness.  Read "The Female Brain" by Louann Brizendine for a really good summary of what happens and all the other interesting things that sets the female brain apart from the male brain.

And even then, that "dead" level still has fluctuations of estrogen in the early stages of the cycle. After all, the cycle itself doesn't pause; it just has a trough and a peak like a Sine curve. The logical conclusion is that the fluctuation of estrogen is always affecting the brain by just a wildly varying amount.

Thus, that begs the question of what is and is not part of a woman's "normal" behavior? What is the normal water in the pot and what is the boiling?

"Thank you, women, for being strong enough to put up with PMS and menstruation".

Guys for the most part don't seem to have any idea of how serious a problem periods can be. So, here's an eye opener. 

15% of women with serious menstrual problems actually try to commit suicide. The physical pain and mental anguish can actually make your life not worth living. These serious complications are common: endometriosis, where the womb-lining has developed elsewhere in the body and tries to shed at the same time (just as painful as it sounds) affects an estimated 10-20% of women, and 5-10% have PCOS, which causes diabetes, awful pain and your body actually tries to turn you male due to being bombarded with testosterone (this is why some chicks have a moustache).

A normal period can be painful enough to make you vomit, and the emotional low can actually make you try to commit suicide (which has happened to me more than once).

If there was ever an important issue that needed awareness, it's this one. Too many women live with huge amounts of pain and discomfort and just don't know where to turn. GP's are, by and large, completely useless. We desperately need solutions and proper information.

I remember reading a cross cultural study about the symptoms of PMS. The study had found that the psychological symptoms of PMS were predominately in the western cultures, where as the physical symptoms of PMS were more common in Eastern cultures. They contributed this to the overbearing social perspective that women are irrational and heretic during their periods in the Western cultures versus other cultures. Of course, this particular study hadn't been reproduced yet (as far as I know) but it does offer an alternative explanation for the psychological symptoms of PMS, especially seeing how some women experience PMS quite differently in terms of irritability and fluctuating moods. I personally, will feel the physical symptoms such as cramping and fatigued, but the psychological aspects are a rarity and usually surrounded by other variables going on.

The comment I am going to write is without regard to my gender.  Indeed, I am a male; however, I will try my best to separate that from my argument.

Primarily, I wish to disagree with the conclusion of this video.  Indeed, women endure a lot of psychological and emotional pain and suffering as a result of having to endure the premenstrual and menstrual symptoms.  Sure, they are also to be acknowledged in their roles as birth-givers.  However, it is important not to undervalue the endurance of males in bearing with hormonal, easily irritated, angry women.  In addition, it would be a mistake in the name of equality to forget about the roles of males in initiating the fertilisation process, supporting the woman during pregnancy, labour, and parenting.

Granted, some of the extremist feminists will not find this comment pleasant, exposing their double-standards.  Feminism at its core is not about female dominance; in fact, it is more crucially centred around equality between men and women.  In that light, much like it is unacceptable for a woman to be beaten/insulted/maltreated by her partner/spouse “just because [he is] having a bad day”, it is equally unacceptable for a man to be beaten/insulted/maltreated by his partner/spouse “just because [she is] having premenstrual symptoms.”  It is a misconception to ever consider that premenstrual symptoms are not manageable; in fact, there are several ways to manage them on both the psychological and the physiological levels.  Furthermore, it is not a valid refutation to say “You have to know how PMS feels like before saying that it isn't an excuse to abusing others.”  In fact, it is not necessary for a person to be a female to know the experience of PMS: males are at the receiving end of the symptoms (at least the psychological ones).

Secondly, this woman is not the least bit funny; if anything, she is very ridiculous and her behaviour makes me cringe.  It would have been more fitting to involve Laci Green in this video, given her interesting way of making such topics fun to discuss.

Finally, I wish to make a concluding remark from anecdotal experience in being at the receiving end of PMS.  Granted, this last paragraph may contain some bias.  Based on personal experience, even when the male is friendly and comforting, he may still be on the receiving end of criticism and verbal abuse.  It is not necessary that a male be provocative or annoying in order for this abuse to occur, as in some cases, it is the female that seeks to “create a scene” to exploit it as an outlet of her anger/irritability.  From a psychological standpoint, this is known as “displacement.”

Everyone is different on how much or how little hormones are released. Same goes for cramping and other pains. Many woman will not experience a period exactly the same; so saying something like "Quit acting like its a big deal because it's not" may be easily said for one person, but not the other(:.

As for all people saying this is justifying women using hormones as an excuse. Personally, I've never heard any female use hormones as an excuse for a bad mood, nor have I used it as an excuse. The only thing I've heard is men accusing women like myself of being pmsing or on their period when they have any sort of emotional reaction to anything. I don't think its fair and rather sexist. Its especially sexist to say women can't have any sort of power because SOME WOMEN experience certain emotional responses to hormonal changes the majority of women go through. Not all women experience emotional or physical changes when pmsing. I for example just get physical symptoms. Headaches, bloating, back pain, fatigue, for usually 10 days before my period. Although I have this physical discomfort I have no emotional changes. I get emotional sometimes, but it doesn't always happen on my period. For those who are emotional on their period it may be hormones but for some it may just be a correlation. And correlation is not causation. Just because a trait of masculinity is expressing less emotion does not mean all men have less emotions then female. They just express emotion differently or not at all. Don't be a sexist asshole :)
